job_title: Service Coordinator in Perry Hall, MD
pros: I love this company. The training and support is amazing. The pay is awesome. It is nice to work some where that respect the workers through action and not just give lipservice.
cons: No cons that I have experienced. Different supervisors styles can hinder some workers. But I am sure that iscan be resolved through chain of command.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Owings Mills, MD
pros: You get to work with some great people on your caseload. As a coordinator or supports planner you can see the impact you’re having on people you serve. Some teams are pleasant to work with and work collaboratively together
cons: - Some people get promoted without taking in feedback from supervisor/manager. - Policies around communication are non existent- staff should know who the point people are on certain topics. It doesn’t always need to be a senior vp or regional vp - There’s so much expertise and natural talent in the agency but the same people are on committees, or have upper management’s ears while others fight to get their voices heard - While staff in people and culture are sweet as pie, reminder—HR is not your friend - check on your SCs and SPs, some of them have been disrespected by family members of clients so badly or even agency staff and when there are no consequences it’s disheartening. - the recent freak out with the audits and over focus on numbers has discouraged staff to leave

pros: Leave and benefits are great Pay is decent Really amazing leads (depends on your catchment)
cons: Very unit focused Not a lot is accounted for travel and team meetings

pros: Autonomy of schedule and rapport/relations. Company is always changing, adapting, and modifying. Rewarding job - working with and for people. Person centered throughout whole company. Met the CEO on the first day of orientation!
cons: Communication. change process is a bit slow or super fast. Company grew exponentially and is now picking up the pieces.

job_title: Coordinator of Community Services in Baltimore, MD
pros: Working with Service Coordination has been a great experience. The supervisor's do try to set the employees up for success. I am able to take time off if I need and doesn't feel like a burden.
cons: Mainly with providers and not responding to e-mails/ phone calls.

review_title: Good place to start and gain experience
pros: A good place to start and gain experience. The pay structure seems good at first glance. High expectations (Laziness should not be rewarded) Nice CEO.
cons: 1. You'll be thrown to the wolves on day one. (You'll gain experience that way) 2. Favoritism is the order of the day. (Play the game and win the price) 3. At a second glance, the pay structure is deeply affected by favoritism. You can be at the same pay rate as your colleague but the supervisor may give you a 2 rating and give her preferred staff a 3-4. That's a difference of nearly $3000 each quarter. So you may both start at $50k but the other may make $62k at the end of the year. (Nice isn't it?) 3. WOMEN, WOMEN, WOMEN! (Need I say more?) 4. This is a corporation disguising itself as a non-profit.

pros: Able to work remotely in your community.
cons: Very difficult to take consecutive days off.

pros: great mission in serving the community
cons: The growth of the organization will definitely keep you busy

job_title: Supports Planner in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Helping people, making a difference and benefits are good.
cons: Billing, bad management, high stress, plans pending for over a year, high turnover, no work life balance.

cons: You will deal with people outside the organization who are dealing with stressful life events and that will take a toll on you eventually. There is also a lot of deadline, paperwork and red tape to go through in the job

cons: Training sessions need improvement, mentors should not be overwhelmed when trying to be a mentor.

review_title: It used to be a great place to work but a change in management really took the agency into a downward spiral.
pros: Loved providing service coordination and support of the individuals in services. Great opportunities to meet a variety of people and to work with many community resources.
cons: Management and administration do not understand the job and do not provide the support needed to complete the job. Their lack of understanding has resulted in many complaints from the state and from provider agencies. Staff feel overwhelmed.

pros: You get to work from home which means you can essentially make your own hours (within the operating hours of the company)
cons: You are expected to get a certain number of billable hours a day/week/month/quarter/year. If you take time off you have to make up the billable hours which can seem impossible at times.

pros: You get to work from home and often meet new people. Great employee bonus program. You get paid mileage. Great supervision!
cons: Even though you get mileage all of the driving can put some wear and tear on your car.

pros: Flexible, decent pay, Paid holidays
cons: Too many demands, Weird co worker, weird management, lack of support, and You’re built up to think you really know your people, but in reality You know nothing and you just shuffle paper work
